Oct 11, 2025

Testing a Drafts.app action

Drafts.app on MacOS

Oct 11, 2025

Drafts.app is a flexible and powerful workhorse on my phone and tablet, but I’ve always been irritated by the way its windows work on the Mac. The main window is always the same size, whether it is just text or I have one or two sidebars open. By contrast, I’m used to Mac apps treating sidebars like a drawer. If I open one, the text window maintains its width and the side bar opens out further.

Today I played a little trick on myself and used Drafts in full-screen mode with an app next to it. In that context, the behavior of Drafts actually makes sense to me. (I’m not making a general statement about the app’s design. Instead, as with most software, I am interested in how well it works for me and the expectations I’ve internalized over the years.)

Having learned this about Drafts, I might be able to make it do more for me on the Mac. Till now, I’ve mainly used it to look up old notes and to get ephemeral text snippets from one device to another. (I feel confident about the app because its notes are stored in JSON files. That means the contents of the backups it regularly does are easy to access with any text editor, regardless of whether I continue to have the app.)

Oct 10, 2025

I’ve been adding posts from a short-lived blog called On My Mac. While doing this, I sometimes hit send before I’ve added a title or set the right date (2007, not 2025). I can fix these errors on my blog right away, but they might still carry over on the blog’s Fediverse feed. Sorry about that.

Photograph of Young Man on Relief in 1940

Oct 9, 2025
Hayward, California [1940]. Youth on Relief. Looking in his pocket for his surplus commodities card. 'Not having a job is bad enough, but you keep goin' down and purty soon you're here and the spirit is gone. I turn my face when somebody I know real well comes along the sidewalk. It takes the spirit when you're in here and then you haven't anything left.'

This image stems from a federal food aid program during the Great Depression. For me, the quoted recipient of aid represents a familiar story about pride, dignity, shame, and fear that the self-righteous who reject the provision of such aid fail to grasp.

Photo and caption by Rondal Partridge for the National Youth Administration, April 17, 1940, from the series Study of Youth Photographs, Record Group 119: Records of the National Youth Administration, National Archives Catalog, NAID: 532121.

Seen in my neighborhood this morning.

Oct 7, 2025

My initial reaction to iOS 26 was with “reduced transparency” turned on. This setting even causes all the little floating menus to be surrounded by an excessive and useless layer of screen-hogging white that hides parts of the screen that were visible under iOS 18. The accessibility setting “reduced transparency” needs a much more nuanced implementation. It is unconscionable that they didn’t design Apple Glass with accessibility in mind from the get-go.

Oct 7, 2025

In a moment of insanity, I let my iPhone SE upgrade to iOS 26. I liked the idea that contextual menu access would be better, and it is. But the rest feels like a practical joke. The UI has all the charm of pieces of construction paper with rough-cut or frayed edges that seek my attention.

I watched Maryna Er Gorbach’s award-winning “Klondike” this evening (Ukraine and Turkey, 2022). It is stunning and raw, Oksana Cherkashyna’s performance breathtaking. I’m going to need time to digest this one. Set in July 2014 where Flight MH17 came down, it is unlike any war film I’ve seen.

Oct 4, 2025

“It‚Äôs a pity how easily people can be fooled.”

‚ÄÉ– Spencer Tracy’s character in “Keeper of the Flame‚Äù (1942)

Oct 4, 2025

I’m watching “Keeper of the Flame” (1942) on HBO Max. A few things in the first third have already got me wondering about the unsettling direction in which I am headed with this wartime release.

Good and bad tended to be more clearly demarcated than what I have seen so far: an uncanny tone surrounding a dead American hero (so-called), the fictional organizations Forward America and Robert Forrest Boys Army for America, the synergy between the dead man and the press, and some on-point quotes about fascists out to enslave us—not with chains but by sowing division and taking hold of our imaginations and loyalty.

Sometimes not knowing is more suspense than I can handle, so I was glad to find a review that confirmed my hunches without offering any spoilers.

“It‚Äôs 2025 ‚Äî Are we ready for What Cukor, Hepburn ,Tracy and Donald Ogden Stewart warned us about Fascism? ‘Keeper of the Flame’ (1942)" by Roger Moore for Movie Nation, April 28, 2025.

Now back to the movie.

Photo of a Woman Sporting a Top Hat and Pipe in 1907

Oct 1, 2025

The modern-day archival title of this old postcard is a gender-neutral "Person in top hat and pipe", although the person pictured appears to be a woman. That there is something gender-bending or gender-ambiguous about it is confirmed by the message on the back, presumably from the person photographed, who was travelling in Ohio.

Sept. 16, 1907

Dear Frances‚Äì

I just couldn't help it, and I knew you would want one, even tho you do have to hide it. I've had some good ones taken and will send you one as soon as they are finished. I've had a lovely time in Galion, but I leave in the morning for Mt. Vernon for a ten day visit then to Columbus and Zanesville for a few days. Dea had me read your letters. I'm glad you are feeling so fine. Yours lovingly Bessa

The condition of the postcard is immaculate because it was not sent in the clear as a postcard but instead placed in an envelope. Note how the handwritten text filled the entire back of the card, covering both the message half and the address half.

The reasons for Bessa's apparently subversive appearance are unclear, but three possibilities come to mind. She could have been a dress reformer, or maybe an entertainer, or simply someone for whom this manner of dress aligned most closely with her sense of self. Regardless, the look on her face and the tone of her text makes me think she she would have been a lovely person to know.

Source of images: Warren and Katherine Head postcard collection, The Newberry Digital Collections, NL12WVEL

I will say, watching the behavior of the Generals today, respectful but reserved and apolitical in the face of Trump was heartening.

Hopefully the next generation of officers, the young ones, see that and take it to heart.

Poster: 'Books are Weapons in the War of Ideas'

Sep 27, 2025
Books cannot be killed by fire.

People die, but books never die. No man and no force can take from the world the books that embody man's eternal fight against tyranny. In this war, we know, books are weapons.

– Franklin D. Roosevelt, on poster titled "Books are weapons in the war of ideas" (U.S. Government Printing Office, Washington, DC, 1942), via Library of Congress, www.loc.gov/pictures/item/96502725/.

A Short Bluesky Thread about Gender Normativity and Violence

Sep 25, 2025

Today on Bluesky, Anna Lind-Guzik noted:

There‚Äôs a reason mass shooters, whether they‚Äôre disaffected brain rotted teens, or adults who kill their families, are men. Obsession with status and control through violence is fundamentally political and patriarchal, and to suggest it isn‚Äôt is to totally ignore feminism.

People are confused because it doesn‚Äôt map neatly along partisan lines, but that‚Äôs because misogyny is so pervasive, not because it isn‚Äôt political.

That got me thinking, so I responded:

That’s a bridge too far for people who want to naturalize gender norms, and we seem to be falling deeper into that territory at the moment. Ironically, the right is trying to get us there by shoring up cultural norms and denaturalizing non-heteronormative people.

To the extent that people don’t question such rhetoric, it is a pretty effective exercise of rhetorical power, that is, reactionary rhetorical violence. Little wonder that gender studies are presented as a threat.

Shared Notes: Indicating a Canonical Link with JSON-LD

Sep 24, 2025

I’ve been looking for a way to indicate to search engines what the canonical link of something I cross-post is. This is relevant for individual blog posts on markstoneman.com that end up becoming a whole newsletter on stoneman.page

I’ll use a human-readable “crossposted from …” statement and link, but I can also place this information inside a JSON-LD script for search engines to parse. The best part: I can put this in the body of a blog post.

<script type="application/ld+json">
{
"@context": "https://schema.org",
"@type": "Article",
"mainEntityOfPage": "https://stoneman.page/newsletter-example",
"headline": "Example",
"url": "https://markstoneman.com/2025/09/24/post-example",
"author": {
"@type": "Person",
"name": "Mark Stoneman"
},
"datePublished": "2025-09-24"
}
</script>

I need to dig around in the documentation more to be sure I have this right. I obtained the above through much back-and-forth with GPT-5 mini, and that LLM contradicted itself in different sessions. The schema.org has a validator. Now I need to learn about other possible keywords. I’d also like to know more about JSON formatting because apparently things like a trailing comma can cause trouble.

Sep 24, 2025

On sunny days, I wake up without an alarm clock. On cloudy days, I’m not sure if I ever wake up

Historian Alexander Karn uses Arthur Koestler’s Darkness at Noon (1940) to highlight a central problem for today’s GOP. Their convictions no longer have any value. Following the whims of Dear Leader is everything. See his “The Problem of Tonnage”. His link to a New Yorker article about Koestler’s novel is paywalled, but you can find the piece on archive.today.

The web is about free movement. If there are walls that keep competitors out and users in, it is not the web.

Streaming

Sep 23, 2025

Stories about the politics and business of media have got me thinking about my streaming choices.

I’m still annoyed at Peacock’s unannounced introduction of ads to the plan I had. I liked a few of their shows, which made their cheapest paid plan for ad-free viewing worth it. Now the cheapest paid plan only gets you limited shows and heaps of ads.

To get what I had for $6.99 and then $7.99, I would have to pay $16.99 per month. That’s a 143.1% increase since 2022. Or a mere 112.6% increase over the $7.99 I was paying when they threw up the ads and I cancelled.

Paramount’s value proposition is going to change for me too because of Colbert’s departure in the spring. The economics of late night talk shows might be growing against them, but I’m one of those people who is not interested in most of the other stuff they stream. Colbert was why I signed up in the first place.

I dropped Netflix after they began insisting that a household had to exist in the same location, whereas real families often live in different locations. Take my eldercare situation, for example. Their programming had already begun to feel bland, like so much processed food.

HBO Max still offers value, but the people who bought Paramount are making eyes at it too, I’ve read. Given the venality and ideological goals of the current administration, owning blatantly oversized shares of the American media market will not be a problem for the FCC.

There is PBS Passport, an affordable option that will probably have to get more expensive, given the Corporation for Public Broadcasting’s defunding. I’m optimistic that public radio and television will survive, but I’m not sure they will be readily available in less prosperous, more rural ares, which are already facing the loss of other services.

I’ll probably do more of what I did when streaming services were less widespread: shop for shows √† la carte. That’s how I watched The Daily Show because I was damned if I was going to pay for cable programming I didn’t want.

I began this kind of streaming around the time that TV disappeared from the airwaves where I lived. Yes, we got our digital converter, for free I think, because broadcast TV was supposed to remain readily available. Most signals didn’t reach us in our apartment in the nation’s capital, so that experiment was short-lived.

Fortunately, Germany’s two big public television broadcasters stream a lot of their shows through the ARD Mediathek and the ZDF Mediathek. Some are geo-blocked, depending on licensing arrangements, but much of it is not. News and comedy from a media market that is more or less still functional is a fine thing.

I don’t know of other international broadcasters that value public diplomacy enough to make such quality programming in their national language freely available overseas. One exception: There’s a joint French-German cultural channel that made the jump to streaming: Arte. Its programming languages seem to be French, German, and English, but not only. The availability of audio and subtitle options depends on the program.

Meanwhile I recently discovered Kanopy, which people can use through their local library. So things aren’t all bad. In fact, there is more to be had now than there ever was when I was growing up next to a mountain that blocked ABC, made CBS and PBS inconsistent, but couldn’t interfere with NBC’s signal from Maine.

When my father’s dementia began to get the better of him, I introduced streaming to my parents' household because the traditional TV package he had through Spectrum was not only too expensive but also too hard to operate. The TV’s Android interface was also impossible, but I found that a Roku streaming stick worked for my mother. With streaming from Paramount and Peacock still affordable, I could play some of my Dad’s favorite shows for him, the ones that he could still follow or at least feel at home with.

Some of the streaming apps have grown messier, though, and my Mom is getting older. I notice she almost always turns to PBS these days (including the news), so gradually dropping the other commercial streaming services hasn’t been an issue so far.

I used to go crazy in this condo because my father always had the TV on, and it was usually loud. He let me turn it down after I assumed the role of caregiver, but it was still always on.

My mother does things differently. She finds that she can process shows better with closed captioning on and the volume off. Now she only uses sound for concerts, ballets, and her church service, which I stream from my computer. The apartment is generally very quiet nowadays.

Sep 23, 2025

“First Black student to graduate during Southern integration dies at 85” by Marianna Bacallao for WPLN News, Sept 23, 2025.

I’m sharing this news about Bobby Cain because I had never heard of the Clinton 12. They integrated an Arkansas hight school in 1956, a year before the famous Little Rock Nine – without the help of the NAACP or federal troops.

It‚Äôs never too late to become more of a human being, less of a machine.

Two New Books to Read Online with My Granddaughter

Sep 21, 2025

I added two new books to the rotation of things I read to my granddaughter via FaceTime and screen sharing. Nowadays, her screen is in London instead of on Cape Cod. I’m glad we’d already developed the habit before she moved. We do it less frequently because of the time difference, but we can easily jump right into a book whenever the opportunity arises.

The first book is The Spark in You by Andrea Pippins (Random House Studio, 2024). It’s about a girl in Brazil, but it is told in the second person, just as the title suggests. I loved talking about the spark in my granddaughter this way while she could imagine herself in the colorful images of a girl preparing for carnival and then attending it. The language is poetic, matching the beauty of the illustrations. It is not the kind of book one just reads, though, because the illustrations are rich in detail and the words more sparse. My granddaughter found lots of details to delight in and talk about.

The second book is Princess Cupcake Jones and the Missing Tutu by Ylleya Fields, illustrated by Michael LaDuca (Belle Publishing, 2013). When my granddaughter heard this title, she observed that it sounds like a mystery. In this case, the protagonist cannot find the one piece of clothing that she always insists on wearing. As she looks for it, she begins finding other missing things in odd places. This tale is less sparing with words, offering rhymes on every page.

A Sunflower Garden Opposite the Russian Embassy in DC

Sep 20, 2025

Anke Stoneman sent me some snapshots of a Ukrainian victory garden opposite the Russian embassy in Glover Park a couple weeks ago. She has generously allowed me to share them here.

A black sign with white text on it explains:

Why are there Sunflowers here?
What is the Polonne Sunflower Garden?

  • Sunflowers are the national flower of Ukraine. When the full Russian invasion of Ukraine began, Sunflowers became a symbol of Ukrainian resistance against Russia‚Äôs brutal aggression.
  • These Sunflowers serve as a symbol of Ukraine‚Äôs eventual victory against this unprovoked invasion, and the hope for a peaceful, prosperous, and free Ukraine.
  • The Polonne (pronounced: pole-own-A) Garden has been planted annually by volunteers since the full Russian invasion began in 2022.
  • This garden is named after the small town in Ukraine that one of the volunteers used to teach in.
  • Please do not sick, trample or cut the sunflowers.

The sunflowers are on private property, so the occupants of the terrorist state's giant Soviet-era compound across the street must coexist with this proud evidence of Putin's folly. They can enjoy it from a bus stop on either side of the street.

A bit further down the hill from the garden is a wooden fence painted in the colors of the Ukrainian flag. Affixed to it are drawings of scenes from Ukrainians apparently showing resolve. The ones I can make out include soldiers. One, working at a terminal, says, "I never thought I'd wear this uniform, but this is my Land!"

Sep 16, 2025

Note to self: when you think someone is a bit more confused than is normal for the time of day, remember to have a look at their glucose monitor readings. Low blood sugar doesn’t always exhibit the same symptoms.

Sep 16, 2025

When I got my COVID booster, I was surprised to learn that one had to have preexisting health conditions to get it when one is under sixty-five. As a matter of practicality, the pharmacy can’t do anything more than ask. Still, this is the kind of policy that can lead to many more preexisting conditions among Americans.

Another takeaway from this bit of news: I’ve been better at ignoring RFK Jr. news than I thought. I imagine most of us are doing this kind of self-care to varying degrees these days. We can’t focus on more than we can handle without going berserk or catatonic.

Make America Great by Making Americans Stateless?

Sep 13, 2025

I’ve been taking my news in limited doses lately, but this story ran across one of my feeds today and managed to unsettle me more than what has become normal since late January.

[Marco] Rubio has already sought to punish immigrants for speech. New legislation might let him do it for U.S. citizens.

– “New Bill Would Give Marco Rubio ‚ÄúThought Police‚Äù Power to Revoke U.S. Passports” by Matt Sledge, The Intercept, Sept. 13, 2025

My off-the-cuff response to the guy who shared this piece: “That would render people stateless and drop them into a legal no man‚Äôs land. It could only be enforced in a very arbitrary manner, perfect for an authoritarian state.”

Hat tip: @MitchW of Mitch’s Blog.

Threads Reprise

Sep 13, 2025

I’m starting an account on Threads again in a limited way. My handle is @stoneman.threads, and my profile reads, “Was here for the first 15 months, but bailed because of slow Fediverse integration. Back to connect with people I can follow from Mastodon.” I’ll do some cross-posting, too, but differently, unless I connect with real people and not just an algorithm.

Updates

Sept. 13

  • Using Threads is proving to be as full of friction as it was during my first time round. I’m also disappointed to see how many accounts do not have Fediverse sharing turned on. If people on Mastodon expressed trepidation about Threads integration into the Fediverse, they needn’t have worried. Threads is not trying to sell the idea, probably because they haven’t figured out how to integrate fully without ceding control over user behavior. Ironically, I think some Threads users are themselves afraid of their posts being shared into the Fediverse at large.

Sept. 15

  • I’ve never experienced a social site as non-responsive and as disrespectful of my browser settings as Threads.

Sept. 16

  • Another example of the unnecessary friction one encounters on Threads: Supposedly Fediverse accounts can be followed from there, but I can’t find any, not even those shown in screenshot examples. The Fediverse feed does not work for me, either.
  • Leaving the first time around was the right decision, but I wanted to learn more about its current level of Fediverse integration. Still lacking. I’m not even sure I know anyone there anymore.
  • Still doing this from a web browser. Different browsers. But the iPhone app is just as unhelpful.

Sept. 23

Still no Fediverse visible.

Also, I forgot to mention my Instagram experience. I had to set up a new account there in order to use Threads. I made it private because I had no intention of using it. Instagram soon claimed that I was violating their terms and conditions and deleted that account. Yet my Threads account still exists.

Is Meta negging ambivalent users? My impression is that they don’t care enough to make even their basic systems work. Take that Instagram account. I was following no one, but the system kept following people for me – not suggesting follows, but actually following them. And I couldn’t unfollow them. Only blocking worked.

Sept. 27

If I am unable to see Fediverse accounts and posts from my new Threads account, I think I must call this experiment a failure. Meta’s chatbot suggests I disconnect from and reconnect to the Fediverse, but that Threads setting says that I can only reconnect after 30 days, if I do this. One more bit of unhelpful, unnecessary friction from a company that doesn’t really trust open systems.

Blog, meet Fediverse, again.

Sep 13, 2025

I go back and forth about having my blog feed automatically sent to the Fediverse because I prefer to mediate how my posts appear there. Nonetheless, I’ve decided to turn on this automatic Fediverse sharing again, while retaining my manual crossposting. It’s possible a few people might prefer this option, so why not? It might also help with search, if my custom Mastodon feed isn’t getting pulled in while my blog’s Fediverse feed is.

The blog’s Fediverse feed is @blogfeed@markstoneman.com. My usual Mastodon account is still @markstoneman@zirk.us. I can be reached either way, but the second gives me more options, including private posts and boosts.

Sep 12, 2025

MAGA’s use of the term “ideology” is yet another projection. Everything about their worldview is ideological: ideology over facts, ideology over reason, ideology over values.

Sep 12, 2025

A couple of the app icons optimized for Liquid Glass are showing weird white or grey partial borders on my iDevices. I'm looking at you Drafts and Overcast (the two on the left of the accompanying image). I hope this is not going to be a widespread phenomenon.

Sep 11, 2025

Note to self: Remember to use Cloudflare’s “purge everything” button when fiddling with your site’s CSS.

Sep 9, 2025

I’ve become comfortable enough with my blogging platform to begin setting up a newsletter. I will do this from a separate domain (stoneman.page) so I can provide a better experience than a newsletter generated directly from my blog could do. More soon.

The Arrogance of Apple's Liquid Glass

Sep 9, 2025

Apple’s promotional video, Introducing Liquid Glass, begins with views inside a glass building. Viewers can delight in the visual effects produced by the different layers of glass as they move through this futuristic space. So far so good, but imagine Apple designers jumping from such vistas to the notion that this aesthetic should translate into a resource-intense environment that is usable, comfortable, even desirable for all users of their products. Yikes!

I’ve been using Apple computers since 1987, when I bought a MacPlus for college. I’ve put up with all their many changes, even the ridiculous, because I could reliably get stuff done with them. With my worsening vision, I’ve still been able to adapt, but I don’t think that will work with the new design. I’m also not keen on buying more processing power to produce Apple’s new visual effects. I appreciate good, clean design, but this isn’t it.

My anger and anxiety about the impending change is fueled by my elder care responsibilities. As Microsoft made my mother’s PC less usable and less safe, especially in my hands, I opted to bring her over to my Mac, while making that experience as familiar as possible. For a woman in her upper 80s, she’s doing pretty well. Dragging her through Apple’s planned changes, though, is a bad idea.

This is a woman who Facebook is also doing its level best to alienate. Only now I’ve got her to the point where she can openly complain about the AI she notices there. Earlier, she would feel embarrassed by her diminishing abilities to use her computer. I told her the problem was with the design changes, not her. I told her about Meta’s algorithm, too. She’s come to accept this point of view and again be reasonably comfortable doing the things she wants.

She’s also come to enjoy an iPad. I initially got one for her to view photos on, but she’s all over solitaire and jigsaw puzzles. I do not plan to let Apple ruin this progress with their thoughtless design decisions and inadequate attention to accessibility needs.

If Apple’s design decisions affected only me, I could install Linux Mint when my current MacOS slows down. But I’d have to know that system a lot better before I could feel confident about making it usable for Mom.

Shared Notes: Header Image and Avatar Formatting Fix

Sep 9, 2025

The previous CSS for my header image and avatar quit working as expected, but I’ve got a fix.

The avatar had changed its size, lost its border, become square, and moved to a different part of the header. I don’t know if this happened because I added microformat classes to my HTML or if the problem lay elsewhere. In any case, here is the revised version of layouts/partials/microhook-profile-photo.html with classes set for my h-card. These classes contain semantic information about what a given thing is, whereas the normal CSS classes style what we post.

<a class="u-url u-uid" href="/">
	<div class="avatar-container">
   		<img class="profile_photo u-photo" src="https://markstoneman.com/uploads/2025/cant-happen-here-avatar.jpg" alt="Mark Stoneman's Avatar">
	</div>
</a>

It seems my original round avatar was working because my setup just assumed something that is in most Micro.blog set-ups. The avatars are round and have a specified size. My HTML had specified the avatar size, but apparently that was no longer working. My CSS now specifies the size and roundness explicitly. See the lines border-radius: 50%; width: 120px; height: 120px; near the bottom of the following declaration block:

.profile_photo {
    border: 3px solid #555;
    position: absolute;
    bottom: -10px;
    left: 10px;
    z-index: 1;
	border-radius: 50%;
	width: 120px;
    height: 120px;
    object-fit: cover;
}

Finally, things can get weird if the big profile image below the avatar is not sized properly. Now the declaration includes a new property and value at the bottom (object-fit: cover;). This line specifies how the image of Nazi book burners should behave if it is not the exact size that my blog theme expects. It should cover the area required without stretching or otherwise distorting its aspect ratio.

Sep 8, 2025

Election poster for the Death Party: “You have to die anyway. Why wait?”

Passerby: “Someone finally says it!”

– From a cartoon in German by Ralph Ruthe, https://troet.cafe/@ralphruthe/‚Ä¶ Sept. 8, 2025

My Current Social Web Tools

Sep 7, 2025

Much has happened since Twitter’s untimely death, so I thought I’d revisit my current setup for the social web.

Mastodon

Since my Ivory subscription was coming up for renewal, I poked around for alternatives that might work for me now. I ended up keeping Ivory for iOS/iPadOS, but I gave up the MacOS version because I don’t use that enough to justify the extra cost. Moreover, I found an excellent web client called Planpy. It works on all devices, but it feels good on my desktop. (Mastodon’s official site does not feel good.)

Bluesky

The official app is only formatted for the phone. I’ve quit using it on my iPad because the experience is subpar. None of the third-party options I’ve tried work as well as the website, so I stick with the website. There are new web clients, but I haven’t felt the need to go looking yet.

Interoperability

There are tools now to bridge a Mastodon account to Bluesky and vise versa; however, there are people on each platform who don’t enable bridging. To follow and interact on both platforms, I still need separate accounts. Fortunately, the conversations do not always overlap. I also don’t worry about becoming overwhelmed because I do not even try to keep up. Instead, I dip into each place the way I would to a coffee shop or pub filled with people I know. I go, I socialize, I leave.

POSSE

To distribute posts from my blog to Mastodon and Bluesky, I use one of three tools, depending on their length and feature set.

Micro.blog, my blog host, offers cross-posting automation. This is perfectly adequate for many, but I prefer a little more control over what is shared and how. Micro.blog also has a crossposting tool for individual blog posts. This lets one see and edit a post before clicking send. I find this option especially good for text-only micro-posts.

I’m still using the iOS/iPadOS app Linky for crossposting as well, especially if I want to generate a text shot with alt text.

Finally, I’ve got a new system for sharing links from this site. See Using Micro.blog and a Different Domain to Create Custom, Privacy-Friendy Short Links.

Blogging

Where Markdown will work, that’s the markup I use. Fortunately, Markdown will also process HTML, which I sometimes need.

Micro.blog offers serviceable apps for MacOS, iOS, and iPadOS, but I prefer its web app. That said, I tend to use these tools to edit text that I’ve already posted, to manage categories, and to manage other aspects of the blog.

With iOS and iPadOS, the fastest way for me to compose posts and upload them to Micro.blog is with Drafts.app. This tool also works on MacOS, but its user interface behaves in unexpected ways in that environment.

On MacOS, I’ve gone back to an old favorite, MarsEdit. If I want more editing power, I use the app’s “Edit with BBEdit” command, take care of business in that editor, maybe preview the post with Marked, and then return to MarsEdit.

I have tried to use Ulysses on iPadOS and MacOS, but it feels clunky nowadays. I used it more while editing academic group blogs because it quickly converts Word documents without requiring a separate Pandoc installation on the Mac. That matters, because Pandoc is a terminal application.

Following Blogs

For RSS feeds, I still use NetNewsWire.

Using Micro.blog and a Different Domain to Create Custom, Privacy-Friendy Short Links

Sep 6, 2025

Since the ruination of Twitter and of Meta’s various platforms, I have started following a simplified IndieWeb approach to blogging and social media called POSSE. I first post on my blog. I do so even for the kind of short posts that Twitter once made famous. Then I share this content to other platforms. In this way, my content, my online identity, and my social connections remain mine, not a maladjusted billionaire’s.

With this approach, I could still share content to the big siloed platforms, but I don’t because I find their values and user experiences intolerable. Currently, I crosspost only to Mastodon and Bluesky.

To make the origin of my cross-posts clearer, going forward, I want to include short links that point to the original posts. These links should not track anyone, and they should be easy for humans to read. That’s why I have decided to create short links manually on the IndieWeb platform Micro.blog, which already hosts my main site.

You will not see these short links on stoneman.blog, however. That site exists only to manage short links and redirects in the Micro.blog dashboard. I will then add the short links to my social media cross-posts in a consistent format, probably “x-post via stoneman.bog/‚Ä¶”

I don’t plan to create such short links for ephemeral microposts, however. That would be overkill. The same goes for link posts with only minimal commentary from me.

It‚Äôs a common refrain that the news industry has failed to come up with a functioning business model in the Internet age, but that‚Äôs not entirely true. Jettisoning the requirement to report news in favor of inciting the rage and fear and hatred of your audience before serving them up ads for guns and bunkers is a perfectly functional business model. It might not be journalism, might be the opposite of journalism, but the checks clear.

– Omar El Akkad, One Day, Everyone Will Have Always Been Against This (Knopf, 2025), chap. 2.

DC Responses to the Federal Invasion

Sep 2, 2025

Federal agents in DC as a “cancer”:

“There is a vibe shift,” says [Madhvi] Bahl about how she perceives D.C. now. “Every time you leave your house in Black and brown parts of the city you end up seeing something, a detention or ICE agents congregating and hassling people, federal agents enforcing fare evasion. You can’t go anywhere without seeing them. They are like cancer.”

Quoted in Martin Austermuhle, “With cellphone cameras and tip lines, D.C. residents find small ways to fight ICE”, The 51st, (Aug. 28, 2025).

As its title suggests, the article is about much more than this stark quote. It provides advice and resources for positive steps one can take when faced by a blight of federal agents. It also provides examples.

Have I mentioned that I love the District?

By the way, The 51st gets its title from the city’s struggle for statehood and civic equality. DC needs to be the 51st state. See dcstatehoodnow.org to learn about the issue from a human rights perspective.

Shared Notes: Updated CSS for Display Grids

Sep 2, 2025

See previous post for context.

/* Use the first class inside all of your div tags for grids, followed by a space and then whichever one of the other grid classes applies. */

.grid {
	display: grid;
	gap: 1rem; 
	align-items: center;
} 

/* two- and three-column grids, respectively, with each item one column wide  */ 

.grid--2 {
	  grid-template-columns: repeat(2, 1fr);
}
.grid--3 {
  grid-template-columns: repeat(3, 1fr);
}

/* a two-column grid, the left column is twice as wide as the right */ 

.grid--2--wide {
  grid-template-columns: 2fr 1fr;
}
@media (max-width: 800px) {
	.grid.responsive {
		grid-template-columns: 1fr;
		align-items: start;
	}
}

/* to add a stack of images in one grid that can sit next to a single, taller image in the neighboring grid and use the same gap width */

.stack {
	display: grid;
	gap: 1rem;
}

I used a combination of grid, grid–2, and stack to handle my images in On the Metro. This grid CSS is more powerful than I thought.

Shared Notes: Image Galleries revisited

Aug 31, 2025

The flex boxes I learned to make before the pandemic are no longer necessary, I’ve learned. Instead, there are new grid layout options for CSS, which, after some back-and-forth with GPT-5 mini on DuckDuckGo, I’ve decided to use. This will be gradual, as I review posts and layouts while trying variations.

Reference guides:

  • CSS Grid Layout Guide by Chris House, CSS-Tricks, Aug. 21, 2025
  • CSS Grid Layout Module, W3Schools
  • CSS Grid Layout by MDN for more detailed reference needs

Below is a comparison of the CSS and HTML for a three by three grid that will turn into a single column on small screens.

New CSS

.grid {
	display: grid;
	gap: 1rem;
}
.grid--3 {
	grid-template-columns: repeat(3, 1fr);
}
@media (max-width: 800px) {
	.grid.responsive {
		grid-template-columns: 1fr;
	}
}

New HTML

<div class="grid grid--3">
	<img src="" class="cols" alt="" width="100%">
	<img src="" class="cols" alt="" width="100%">
	<img src="" class="cols" alt="" width="100%">
	<img src="" class="cols" alt="" width="100%">
	<img src="" class="cols" alt="" width="100%">
	<img src="" class="cols" alt="" width="100%">
	<img src="" class="cols" alt="" width="100%">
	<img src="" class="cols" alt="" width="100%">
	<img src="" class="cols" alt="" width="100%">
</div>

Old CSS

.flex-container {
    display: flex;
    flex-direction: row;
    align-items: center;
    justify-content: space-between;
}
.flex-three-column {
    flex: 33%;
    padding: 5px;
}
@media (max-width: 800px) {
    .flex-container {
        flex-direction: column;
    }
}

Old HTML

<div class="flex-container">
<div class="flex-three-column">
	<img src="" class="cols" alt="" width="100%">
	<img src="" class="cols" alt="" width="100%">
	<img src="" class="cols" alt="" width="100%">
</div>
<div class="flex-two-column">
	<img src="" class="cols" alt="" width="100%">
	<img src="" class="cols" alt="" width="100%">
	<img src="" class="cols" alt="" width="100%">
</div>
<div class="flex-two-column">
	<img src="" class="cols" alt="" width="100%">
	<img src="" class="cols" alt="" width="100%">
	<img src="" class="cols" alt="" width="100%">
</div>
</div>

Cookie Baking Lists from My Grandmother

Aug 30, 2025

While sorting through a jumble of things my mother has been saving, I ran across a box of index cards (3" x 5") and small pieces of notepaper that her mother had used for cookie recipes in her later years. I had seen these in her kitchen back in the day, but I took a fresh look and found that she had also used the box for record-keeping.

A card with the heading “Total cookies by year” captures her output between 1977 and 1985. A second card has a line drawn down the middle with one entry (top-left) for her Christmas cookie ingredient costs in 1981 and another (top-right) for her mince pie filling costs the same year. The way she formatted this data suggests she had intended to repeat these calculations in subsequent years.

There are also some lists of the kinds of Christmas cookies she baked in a given year, including their number and approximate size.

When I was a kid, Grandma used to tell us how many of each kind we could have, whenever she set out a fresh plate of Christmas cookies. I had a vague idea of the scale of her operation, for I had helped occasionally, or at least cleaned out some bowls with a spatula and my tongue. This accounting, on the other hand, surprised me. Not Mom, though. She chuckled and said sure, cookies had been serious business for Grandma.

The seasonal goodies were not just consumed in the home but also went out in parcels to family and friends in other parts of the country. Mom still has early childhood memories linked to rationing in World War Two. Her father, a history and social studies teacher, would not allow her mother to turn to the black market to maintain her usual levels of Christmastime baking. [Correction: Mom reports that during her childhood, most of the cookie packages were delivered in person.]

The apparent decline in numbers over the years covered in the notes that have survived probably relates to her age, but also to the number of kids still at home. (In these times she had her own place, which was attached to ours. Hers was the right side of the red house shown at the bottom of this post). I imagine the mortality of people to whom she sent Christmas cards and packages also played a role because she had been the youngest of six children. I certainly remember her exchanging fewer cards over time, though not for lack of effort.

If these cards seem trivial to some, they tell the story of a family role she had learned earlier in life. She lost her father as a child and her mother in adolescence, so she probably learned a good deal from the women in her husband’s farming family in Illinois. Doing this accounting at her kitchen table in New Hampshire probably conjured up memories not only of her daughter’s large family, who she had joined in 1970, but also earlier memories from her long life of love and loss, laughs and worries. (She was widowed already in the mid-1950s.)

Her old notes—and the visible chocolate stain on the card with the annual totals—bring me back to my youth, even if I was overseas for several of the Christmases listed here. Did she mail me any cookies when I was in the army? I can’t remember, though I recall the care packages of oatmeal cookies she sent while I was an undergraduate student at Dartmouth College. I think at least one batch of oatmeal cookies made its way to Germany via my APO (Army Post Office) address. They travelled well.

One gets rid of a lot of paper in one’s life. That this little box of Grandma’s cookie baking notes has survived some twenty-two years since her passing says something about their importance in Mom’s memory too. So I will honor them, keep them. Whether my son and granddaughter do the same will be up to them. In any case, my son and his great-grandmother (“Oma”) were lucky enough to have each other in their lives until he was some twelve years old.

Shared Notes: More Tiny Theme Tweaks

Aug 14, 2025

Issues addressed here:

  1. Modification of post categories on individual blog posts
  2. Modification of avatar appearance to include a background header image
  3. Host fonts locally (to do)

Post Categories

I wanted to sort the categories after each post. Since I don’t know the Go programming language, I turned to the LLMs on offer on DuckDuckGo.

ChatGPT struggled with the problem and took me around in circles. Then I tried o4-mini, and it solved my problem on the first go.

Each individual post on this blog is produced with the layouts/posts/single.html template. It is possible to modify the presentation of the categories by adding a layouts/partials/microhook-categories.html file. But what code from the single.html template to include and how to sort the categories? That is the Go programming language problem that o4-mini solved for me.

Then I added a # before each category term inside the link and &#8196; (for an em space) after each term outside the link.

The resulting code for the micro hook:

{{ with .Params.categories }}
  {{ $cats := sort . }}
  <ul class="post-tags">
    {{ range $cats }}
      {{ $term := $.Page.Site.GetPage (printf "/categories/%s" (urlize .)) }}
      <li>
        <a href="{{ if $term }}{{ $term.RelPermalink }}{{ else }}{{ "/" | relURL }}{{ end }}">
          #{{ title . }}‚ÄÑ
        </a>
      </li>
    {{ end }}
  </ul>
{{ end }}

Avatar and Header Image

See the update Shared Notes: Header Image and Avatar Formatting Fix.

I added a header image behind the avatar that Micro.blog themes usually display. To do this, I used Tiny Theme’s option for another micro hook: layouts/partials/microhook-profile-photo.html.

Coming from WordPress, I never had to solve such problems from scratch, so I got a little help from the above LLMs. The microhook html:

<a href="/">
	<div class="avatar-container">
		<img 
			src="https://eu.uploads.micro.blog/166262/2025/cant-happen-here-avatar.jpg" 
			alt="Mark Stoneman's Avatar" 
			class="profile_photo" 
			width="120" 
			height="120">
	</div>
</a>

The accompanying CSS, which maintains the theme’s responsiveness is as follows:

.avatar-container {
    position: relative;
    width: 100%;
    max-width: 768px;
    height: 172px;
    background-image: url('/uploads/2025/book-are-weapons-header.jpg');
    background-size: cover;
    background-position: center;
}

.profile_photo {
	border: 3px solid #555;
    position: absolute;
    bottom: -10px;
    left: 10px;
    z-index: 1;
}

@media (max-width: 768px) {
    .avatar-container {
        height: 140px;
    }
}

I also cleaned up my custom style sheet because all the little tweaks were making it harder to read.

Fonts

I still want to tweak the site’s fonts to make everything more readable. Thing is, though, not all computers have the same fonts preloaded. Many sites use style sheets that call up specific Google Fonts, which are great. Unfortunately, this practice gives Google some sort of tracking opportunity, which in turn means I would have to add a GDPR notice for European visitors.

What to do? Some helpful people have pointed out that hosting fonts locally on Micro.blog is quite easy. I can use Google Fonts this way legally without the tracking.

Once I do this, I will need to modify the fonts section of this site’s privacy notice.

Reliable DC News in the Face of Federal Gaslighting

Aug 14, 2025

If you want to stay informed about the federalization of DC, 51st.news is a great source. Here’s the latest from their local perspective: “Trump‚Äôs D.C. ‚Äòtakeover‚Äô: What we know so far ‚Äî and where we‚Äôre headed.".

Keep in mind that incendiary right-wing rhetoric about cities is the same everywhere, but DC is in a peculiar position. A city of some 700,000 people, it still has no representation in Congress. Worse, Congress can interfere with its home rule.

I find it hard to forgive Democrats who never made DC statehood a priority. Maybe this administration’s actions will help focus Americans' attention on what should be a national issue. DC Statehood is overdue!

Puck Cartoon: 'Fill That Cell!' (1908)

Aug 12, 2025

Cartoon by Art Young in Puck, February 19, 1908, via Library of Congress, https://www.loc.gov/pictures/item/2011647283/.

The above cartoon criticized the unequal treatment of criminality in the United States. Ordinary people were locked up for all kinds of small offenses, whereas white-collar crime went unpunished.

The people in the cartoon speaking this criticism represented ordinary men and youth jailed for various petty crimes. The subtitle, “The Cry of the Small Crook,” makes their status clear. The sign on the small empty cell in the middle reads, “For the Incorporated Law Breaker,” meaning companies, or rather the men who owned and ran them. But that space was empty, so the inmates demanded, “Fill That Cell!” They wanted to see the big fish imprisoned, the white-collar crooks. Otherwise, where was the justice?

'Maidan: Uprising in Ukraine' ‚Äì 2014 Documentary

Aug 11, 2025

Sergei Loznitsa’s 2014 documentary “Maidan: Uprising in Ukraine” is available on Kanopy. By now, I know the story of Ukraine’s Revolution of Dignity from other material I’ve read, watched, and listened to since February 2022, but this film was still a worthwhile experience for me.

Instead of summarizing and analyzing events, it lets them unfold in front of a series of seemingly stationary cameras, with longer intervals from each perspective. This approach permitted me to experience the crowds and the individuals who comprised them viscerally. It made the power of contemporary Ukrainian patriotism palpable.

This force is not an ethnic solidarity but a civic one. It continues to frustrate Putin’s murderous ambitions, while demanding democratic accountability from Ukrainians' political leadership. It is what attracts so many foreigners to its cause.

Shared Notes: New Summary Option in Micro.blog Posts

Aug 11, 2025

Micro.blog now has the option to add a summary to individual posts. These are useful in the Micro.blog timeline, but I don’t want them appearing on the blog itself. To that end, this is the code that needs to be removed from layouts/index.html:

{{ else if .Params.custom_summary }}  
<div class="p-summary">
<p>{{ .Summary | safeHTML }}</p>
</div>

Apparently these summaries are now also included in Micro.blog’s implementation of the Bluesky and Mastodon APIs. They show up in cross-posts to those platforms. They are also likely to show up in some thumbnail views of links on social media.

Update, Aug. 12: For posts without a title, these summaries will take the place of the main content in the post list on the archive page.

Update, Aug. 13: To remove this summary from archive pages for specific categories, remove the same code from the file layouts/_default/list.html. I did this because these category pages present as regular blog pages, and a two line summary is confusing in that context.

'The Negro Soldier' (U.S. Department of War, 1944)

Aug 10, 2025

YouTube’s algorithm churned up an interesting 1944 War Department movie titled “The Negro Soldier” (40 min). It seems to have been aimed at the African American community, appealing to their patriotism. The first part recounts African American military contributions from the Revolutionary War through World War I, while ignoring contemporary divisions in U.S. society and the history that produced them.

Remaining silent on the ongoing violence against people of color in the United States, the film instead has white supremacy speak through the translated words of Adolf Hitler in Mein Kampf, read by an African American minister to his large, all-Black congregation. If Nazis offered a convenient target toward which to steer the struggle for racial equality, the church setting of the film played to Black respectability, family, community, faith, and dignity.

The military training segments of the film focus primarily on combat roles. The menial labor and service positions to which most were relegated only make a brief appearance in the last five minutes, before images of combat quickly obscure them. The film shows many images of all-Black troop formations without openly discussing segregation. On the other hand, it places individual African American men among their white counterparts in a few shots of the initial processing of new enlistees and of officer training.

The film ends with the hymns “Onward Christian Soldiers” and “Joshua Fought the Battle of Jericho,” followed by the final notes of “My Country, ‘Tis of Thee.” If it is silent on racial inequality and unrealized civil rights in America, the implications of its message were more subversive. How could Black soldiers be expected to fight for freedom overseas but submit to tyranny at home?1

  1. See Maria H√∂hn and Martin Klimke, A Breath of Freedom: The Civil Rights Struggle, African American GIs, and Germany (Palgrave Macmillan, 2010). ↩︎

Aug 10, 2025

The eighties-inspired film “Freaky Tales” (Lionsgate, 2025) by Ryan Fleck and Anna Boden has heart, style, and gore. The violence is over-the-top, but not unremitting. Besides, most of the blood spills satisfyingly from the bodies of nazi creeps.

Nazi Propaganda Photo and Caption Prefigure Putinesque Propaganda

Jul 30, 2025

Putin’s regime and its supporters would have us believe that Russia’s 2022 invasion of Ukraine is purely defensive. This 1939 propaganda image by Heinrich Hoffmann and its accompanying caption offered a similarly cynical story in the run-up to Germany’s invasion of Poland.

England lives in groundless fear of war. Their armaments are of monstrous proportions. Our picture shows the new English anti-aircraft [gun].1

In this tall tale, Britain appeared as the aggressor, arming for no good reason. The giant anti-aircraft cannon was meant to suggest “monstrous” bellicosity.

  1. NYPL Digital Collections, image ID 3946333, in the collection “Eye on the Reich: German propaganda photographs, 1939-1942.” ↩︎

Jul 30, 2025

I’ve been trying out a web app for Mastodon called Phanpy. So far, so good. It might soon become my default.

To try it out, login with your own Mastodon account(s) at phanpy.social. Project details are at github.com/cheeaun/phanpy.

Jul 20, 2025

Finished reading Victoria Amelina, Looking at Women Looking at War: A War and Justice Diary (St. Martin’s Press, 2025). The author was killed before she could complete it, but it is still an important little book. It provides insights into Ukrainian cultural and psychological responses to the war, links between past and present generations of Ukrainian cultural producers, and efforts to record war crimes for future accountability. It offers ruminations not only on legal accountability but also on the relationship between memory, narrative, and justice. In this way, her thoughts are about Ukraine, but also about people more generally.

“The First Time America Tried Mass Deportation It Was a Disaster. Why Would We Consider Trying It Again?" by Claudio Saunt, Politico, October 25, 2015.

Jul 16, 2025

Interesting German‚ÄìItalian story of World War Two resistance and memory on ARTE: “Bella ciao! German Soldiers in the Italian Resistance” (53 min).

Evidence of children playing in the neighborhood

Jul 13, 2025

“The Wipers Times” (Trademark Films, 2014) is a movie about a satirical trench newspaper put out by British sappers in Belgium and France during the First World War. I enjoyed it on its own merits and because it was good to see this type of publication featured in film.

Jul 13, 2025

I watched a timely, if now bittersweet political movie this evening: “All the Way” (HBO Films, 2016). It stars Bryan Cranston as Lyndon B. Johnson during his eventful first year in office, which saw passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. I highly recommend it.

The response to truth is often even more truth; that is why regimes fear even small bits of it.

– Victoria Amelina, Looking at Women Looking at War (St. Martin’s Press, 2025), Part I (“Among the Guiding Stars—Oleksandra Matviichuk I”)

Dorothy Thompson on the Folly of American Isolationism

Jul 4, 2025

The United States is not a forgotten Elysian island. Our two oceans connect us with the rest of the world; they do not separate us. They are carrying, at this moment, machine tools, automobiles, raw materials, and all manner of manufactured goods to the whole world and they are bringing here other materials, such as rubber, tungsten, and tin, that are absolutely essential to the continuance of production at even its present level. They protect us, still, from armed attack upon our soil, but they do not protect us from assaults upon our economy or upon the public mind. They in no way relieve us of the responsibility of doing everything that a great nation can do to maintain a world order in which the interests of its people, and the values that they cherish, can survive and improve.

– Dorothy Thompson, Let the Record Speak (Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co., 1939), p. 9

Justice and Peace or Tyranny and Violence?

Jul 4, 2025

We in the United States were once on a path of gradual, if uneven reform, expanding human rights protections and equality of opportunity. Achieving these ends came to entail protecting or expanding access to safe drinking water, clean air, nourishing food, reliable health care, and good public education. Of course, we often fell short on these goals, but we understood that they mattered. The question was less whether they were desirable and more about how to achieve them. Or so many of us thought.

Now our federal institutions have been captured by a party of extremists hell-bent on violating human rights and limiting opportunities for all but the most prosperous. The grotesque bill Congress has just passed will help them realize these goals, making a mockery of our best political traditions, not least our Declaration of Independence, now 249 years old. Our elected leaders, many representing heavily gerrymandered districts and most beholden to moneyed interests, have chosen to exacerbate already unprecedented economic inequalities and to limit or eliminate equality of opportunity.

If we do not course correct, if we do not vote these bums out of office and demand or do better ourselves, we can look forward to the end of comity. Instead of gradual, if often bumpy or unsettling change, we’ll get brutal, systematic oppression followed eventually by violent, institution-destroying revolution. Imagine something like the French Revolution or the Russian/Bolshevik Revolutions instead of the American Revolution. The last of these, in many respects, sought to defend rights and institutions, if at enormous cost to the people we continued to enslave, expropriate, and drive off the land. By defending and reforming our system of government, our leaders avoided the bloody fate of King Louis XVI, and the country grew, redefining itself to include ever wider circles of people.

Can we return to a path of reform? Or will we allow our leaders to exacerbate our differences to the point where too many conclude that violent revolution is the only way to re-establish liberty and justice for all?

Related Posts

  • Received Rights versus Human Rights in the ‘Declaration of Independence’
  • Timothy Snyder and the Existential Significance of History

Western journalists are ‚Ä¶ taught to report various interpretations of the facts. The adage that there are two sides to a story makes sense when those who represent each side accept the factuality of the world and interpret the same set of facts. Putin‚Äôs strategy of implausible deniability exploited this convention while destroying its basis. He positioned himself as a side of the story while mocking factuality. ‚ÄúI am lying to you openly and we both know it‚Äù is not a side of the story. It is a trap.

May 24, 2025

Julia Davis, “Russia to Ukraine: “You want a Ceasefire and I Want You Dead'” at CEPA, May 21, 2025 ‚Äì

The Kremlin‚Äôs propagandists are in a joyous mood as they anticipate US disengagement from the Ukraine conflict.

Davis’s insights come from her study and translation of prominent Russian-language talk shows.

As always, the most accurate assessment of the mood in the Kremlin came not from its robotic public statements, but from its highly-paid propagandists in the TV studios. Since they are regularly briefed by the Kremlin‚Äôs handlers on what they can and can‚Äôt say, their scripted narratives and carefully crafted discussions offer the best window into the regime‚Äôs views and aims.

This was also true after the May 19 telephone conversation between Putin and US President Donald J. Trump about a possible peace deal in Ukraine.‚Ä¶

Read the whole piece for her latest snapshot of where Kremlin minds are at.

Check out her YouTube channel, Russian Media Monitor, to experience clips of the scripted talk shows firsthand‚Äîwith English subtitles.

BTW, if we know each other, and you’d like to reach out yourself, my contact details are on markstoneman.com/about.

May 22, 2025

I really enjoyed “Red Desert” (Il deserto rosso), dir. Michelangelo Antonioni (Italy, 1964), starring Monica Vitti and Richard Harris. It was a visual feast with understated drama. The camera moves slowly, inviting viewers to look at and see the industrial and seaside landscapes, the factory technology and domestic interiors, the refuse and pollution, the faces and postures of individuals, the colors.

Giuliana, the protagonist, is a troubled middle-class woman who was once hospitalized after a largely silenced event that still affects her. The film invites us to try and relate the sounds, smells, and textures of the protagonist’s social and physical surroundings to her inner life as the social interactions and dialogs unfold.

May 22, 2025

There is a charming road movie on Arte called “The Little Brother” (Tajikistan, 1991), made at a particular moment in history, between the Soviet Union’s dissolution and the Tajik Civil War. It is about a seventeen-year-old who would like to leave home, but can’t because he is responsible for his seven-year-old brother. He wants his father, who lives in the countryside, to take responsibility for the kid once more, but that doesn’t work out.

The black-and-white film centers on a trip to their father’s place. They get there and back on a small freight train, whose driver takes on the occasional passenger and parcel via a barter system. Viewers get to experience the Tajik landscape and moments of rural life from the moving train. Sometimes the train stops, affording encounters with other people. The accompanying soundtrack is fantastic.

May 12, 2025

I’ve been streaming the Franco-Belgian detective series “Astrid et Rapha√´lle” (aka “Astrid” and “Bright Minds”) on PBS, and I’m really enjoying it. The autistic Astrid is a compelling character, and Sara Mortensen plays her with love and respect. Granted, I know too little about autism, but I find the show’s effort to integrate other members of Astrid’s evening autistic discussion group helps to round out her character. Then we get to see people with diverse jobs, not to mention varying experiences and abilities vis-√†-vis interactions with the neurotypical. Occasional flashbacks to her childhood and youth help too. In the end, though, the series is still a detective show. The police archivist Astrid, solves crimes with a detective who is unafraid to follow leads uncovered by Astrid that her male colleagues would prefer to ignore: Rapha√´lle (Comandante Coste), played by Lola Dewaere.

May 11, 2025

I watched a film about Nicholas Winton, who helped rescue 669 children from Prague before the Wehrmacht occupied the city. I’m usually not attracted to this subject on screen, but I found “One Life,” dir. James Hawes (Bleeker Street, 2024), both absorbing and affecting. Much of its poignance comes from its shifts between an old man in the late 1980s and his memories of the late 1930s. Anthony Hopkins, who must have been 85 or 86 when he played the lead, is brilliant.

May 9, 2025

I thought the Library of Congress was Congress’s, not a plaything of the executive.

Toward a Mixed Parliamentary‚ÄìPresidential System in the U.S.?

May 7, 2025

A strange thought has been bouncing around in my head lately. If the current administration gets its way regarding how the various departments and agencies are run, even whether or not money appropriated by Congress for them is spent in the first place, that could do more than simply create a governance and democracy problem for the country. Presidential overreach and malfeasance could force Congress to adopt radically different solutions to the national problems we want and need it to address.

Most dramatically, it could consider establishing administrative bodies responsible directly to it, not to the executive branch. Assuming the United States survived whatever the interim brought, the Trump‚ÄìMAGA‚ÄìDOGE approach to politics and rule could eventually lead the way to a more parliamentary form of government that limited the president’s role to the things specifically enumerated in the Constitution. The Necessary and Proper Clause speaks to Congress, after all, not the executive.

This idea still sounds outlandish to me, mainly because I don’t see the administration getting away with its unitary executive theory. If it does, however, then Congress would have to start thinking hard about what is necessary and proper, even removing agencies and departments from the executive branch. Or it could starve these institutions of funds and set up its own. Trump and DOGE have already done a lot of work to make this last option possible.

The president would still have his plenary powers to appoint major officials with the consent of the Senate, but Congress would be under no obligation to fund this cabinet beyond whatever it deemed prudent. Over time, Congress might find it necessary and appropriate to appoint officials from within its own ranks with duties that resemble those of a prime minister and that legislator’s cabinet. If the U.S. president has too much power and can’t be trusted to exercise it with prudent restraint, why shouldn’t Congress begin governing in a way that might lead in this direction?

Parliamentary government might not be the specific goal, but reining in an out-of-control executive certainly needs to be. The result could then well turn out to be a place not unlike where monarchical misrule led in Britain. If the Supreme Court oversteps in order to defend an authoritarian executive, Congress could seek a remedy there as well, changing its size and structure, for example. In short, the extreme degree of power that the Trump administration is trying to assert need not end in the direction they seek or in the pre-MAGA status quo either.

Of course, the nation itself is currently too divided for such sweeping legislation, which would require veto-proof majorities, at least initially. Nonetheless, state initiatives to require run-off elections or weighted voting could yield legislators with more nuanced views and the desire and ability to work for their constituents instead of for a tyrant.

May 7, 2025

Timothy Snyder summing up Russia’s relationship to NATO from 1999 to 2010:

The eastward enlargement of NATO in 1999 was not presented by Putin as a threat. Instead, he tried to recruit the United States or NATO to cooperate with Russia to address what he saw as common security problems. After the United States was attacked by Islamist terrorists in 2001, Putin offered to cooperate with NATO in territories that bordered Russia. Putin did not present the EU enlargement of 2004 as a threat. On the contrary, he spoke favorably that year of future EU membership for Ukraine. In 2008, Putin attended the NATO summit in Bucharest. In 2009, Medvedev allowed American aircraft to fly over Russia to supply troops in Afghanistan. In 2010, Russia‚Äôs ambassador to NATO, the radical nationalist Dmitry Rogozin, expressed his concern that NATO would leave Afghanistan. Rogozin complained of NATO‚Äôs lack of fighting spirit, its ‚Äúmood of capitulation.‚Äù He wanted NATO troops at Russia‚Äôs border.

Source: Snyder, The Road to Unfreedom: Russia, Europe, America (Tim Duggan Books, 2018), chap. 3.

'Nothing but the Truth' (Sony Pictures, 2008)

May 7, 2025

I recently watched “Nothing but the Truth” and found it to be engaging because of how rooted it is in its time, even as the issues it treats are much more broadly relevant. At its heart is the freedom of the press versus the federal government’s powers of coercion in ostensible national security matters. Womanhood and especially motherhood are also important to the story, with mainstream gender norms employed to help viewers relate to (or feel no sympathy for) the woman who the government attempts to coerce. The film is a work of fiction, but its author, Rod Lurie, draws on real events for its initial premise.

During the movie’s first ten or twenty minutes, I got nostalgic vibes because there is a news-making national newspaper in DC that hasn’t been corrupted by a billionaire, a newspaper whose print distribution still matters. There is an FBI that follows the law, and reporters who think that officials lying is newsworthy, even if short attention spans run counter to this belief. The DC location, regardless of where it was actually filmed, was also familiar because of the occasional overlap between work life and home life, even if the filmmakers restricted that overlap to the two main women characters, a journalist and an outed spy.

As the film went on, I was reminded of how out-of-control the federal government can get when pursuing an administration’s aims because the judiciary typically defers to the executive branch on national security matters. The movie shows the U.S. government trying to coerce a reporter to give up her source: it jails her for contempt during a grand jury investigation. Her loss of liberty lasts for nearly a year before there is even a court decision on the specific issues involved. Images of the reporter being transported in leg chains still resonate today. The CIA adds a further low by threatening its own outed agent, reminding her about her upcoming custody hearing.

Since the journalist and the outed spy are both moms, the film connects the two on a personal level by situating their daughters in the same school. The women both volunteer in the school, but don’t know each other personally in the beginning, although the journalist knows the other woman’s child because of her particular volunteer duties. (If any fathers volunteer, it doesn’t come up.) Why is motherhood relevant to the plot? The jailed and then imprisoned journalist pays a high personal cost, being unable to see her young son and probably losing her husband. At the same time, this personal cost can be interpreted by some viewers as her putting a principle ahead of her duty as a mother.

At the very end of the movie, we see that the journalist’s initial unintentional source (before she began her actual reporting) had been her son’s classmate, the daughter of the outed CIA agent. This makes her principled stand for freedom of the press also about protecting a child. Perhaps, for some people, this lets her off the hook for leaving her own son without a mother for so long. Unfortunately, it also almost overshadows the constitutional issues behind her refusal to be coerced by the U.S. government. Or is that the point? Is this another example of the personal manifesting as political?

May 6, 2025

Yesterday I received my first ever skeptical question about my wearing a mask in the grocery store. I doubt she was from around here because we are pretty much live-and-let-live in NH, which is not unlike DC in this respect. üò∑

May 6, 2025

I am a sucker for a good Jean Arthur movie, so I was happy to run across “Only Angels Have Wings” (Columbia Pictures, 1939), in which she plays opposite Cary Grant. I remember enjoying it once or twice before, and I wasn’t disappointed this time either. The movie offers good actors, believable and often likable characters, and a gripping tale centered around a dangerous air mail and air freight business connecting a small South American port to remote areas in the mountains with small aircraft and harrowing flight conditions.

May 5, 2025

I enjoyed the pre-Code film "Ladies They Talk About" (Warner Bros., 1933), starring Barbara Stanwyck. This fast-paced drama features a bank robbery, a revivalist with a radio program, and an interesting portrayal of inmates in a women's ward at San Quentin State Prison. The film also offers sex appeal and comic relief.

Image: Ad clipped from the studio's pressbook ("merchandising plan") at the Internet Archive, archive.org‚Ä¶.

May 4, 2025

In the beginning was the word, and shit got weird‚Ä¶

Photo of 1909 Child Labor Protest

May 1, 2025

Child labor protest, probably in New York City on May 1, 1909. Note the U.S. flag that the girl wearing a sash in Yiddish is holding. The girl with a sash in English seems to be holding a flag, too, albeit one in a single color, perhaps socialist red. The message on the sashes is uncompromising: “ABOLISH CHILD SLAVERY!”

Bain News photograph, via Library of Congress, https://www.loc.gov/pictures/item/97519062.

'Women and Children First' by Theo Matejko, ca. 1939

Apr 27, 2025

Source: "'Bombs Over Us': Prophetic Drawings by a German Artist," Life, September 11, 1939, pp. 27--28, via "a book ‚Ä¶ recently published in Germany," presumably Das Theo Matejko-Buch: Zeichnungen als Aufzeichnungen aus zweieinhalb Jahrzehnten (Berlin: Kommodore-Verlag, 1938).

 

This drawing imagining an air war coming to Berlin was one of a series that Theo Matejko conceived before Germany and the Soviet Union invaded Poland. It seems to convey antiwar sentiment, but the artist supported the Nazi regime, and he regularly contributed to the propaganda magazine, _Die Wehrmacht_. Given this context, his drawing and the following public explanation might be understood as projection instead.

An idea which came to me years ago with unholy force and persistence was the image of an air attack over a big city in some future war. I saw in this dreadful vision the merciless heavens pouring destruction upon peaceful people.‚Ä¶ I offer these pictures in the deep and sincere hope that these nightmare visions may never become a reality.

The drawing doesn’t capture anywhere near the reality, but it offers up two powerful national symbols, the Brandenburg Gate and German motherhood. The choice of the latter was an effective way to underline the indiscriminate nature of this kind of warfare while portraying the Germans as innocent victims.

Apr 26, 2025

Congress was once the proud equal of the executive and judicial branches of our government. Now it stands drained of both power and respect, partly through abdication of its responsibilities and partly through the eager gathering of power by a burgeoning presidency. That phenomenon started with Franklin Roosevelt, and every President since has been unable to resist taking more decision-making responsibility on himself. The power to make war and to decide how our money is spent is no longer the unquestioned province of Congress ‚Ä¶

– “Fresh Blood for a Sick Congress,” Life, November 17, 1972, p. 42.

Apr 25, 2025

The creatures out back are even louder tonight.

Apr 24, 2025

JD Vance is terrible at most things, including passing for a human, but he has accomplished one thing I wouldn’t have thought possible: He’s made me nostalgic for Mike Pence. üëÄ

Apr 24, 2025

Sounds of spring this evening (10 seconds)

Apr 24, 2025

I distracted myself from contemporary authoritarianism with the wonderful 1954 Italian film “Chronicle of Poor Lovers” (Cronache di poveri amanti). It takes place in Florence in the mid 1920s and focuses on the lives of people in the Via del Corno. Everybody seems to know everyone else’s business in this street, and life seems pretty normal, even good, despite material privations. But there are also the whispers and occasional off-key tones of a few fascists. Then comes a brutal beating and later the work of a death squad, with individual residents among the murderers and the murdered. The film’s title references the young couples that are broken up and formed in the course of this adversity.

Apr 24, 2025

Who needs a department of education or a legislature when we have the executive orders and social media posts of a malicious, camera-addicted, very presidential, orange buffoon?

Apr 24, 2025

“The Murderers Are Among Us” (Die M√∂rder sind unter uns), dir. Wolfgang Staudte (DEFA, 1946), is streaming on Arte. Filmed in the rubble of early postwar Berlin, it represents an important attempt to come to terms with Germany’s immediate past and to see a way through the present.

Hildegard Knef and Wilhelm Borchert

Child Labor as 'Necessity' (1912 Cartoon)

Apr 22, 2025

“NEXT! From the Cradle to the Mill” Cartoon by Art Young for Puck, April 10, 1912, via Library of Congress, https://www.loc.gov/pictures/item/2011649137/.

Note the big shadowy black ghoul labeled “NECESSITY” leading a young girl out of a dark, impoverished room toward a factory on the right, where two other children are facing a sign at the entrance that reads, “Machinery Operated by Children” and “MEN NEED NOT APPLY.” The image of the little girl clutching her doll as she is forced to leave behind her book, paper, toys, and other small items on the floor usually a part of childhood flourishing makes this brutal uprooting from her home appear unnatural.

What’s more, the preference of the factory for cheaper children over more expensive men characterizes the practice of child labor as a vicious circle. If men are not welcome at the factory, if the lifeless woman at the table is unemployed, and if the children are not in school, the family will not be able to improve its lot, no matter how hard the children toil. This point is underlined by the cartoon’s subtitle, “From the Cradle to the Mill,” a play on the common phrase, “from the cradle to the grave.”

Margarita Simonyan's Death Wish

Apr 22, 2025

The pro-Kremlin media personality Tigran Keosayan has been in a coma since late December. Recently, his grief-stricken wife, RT chief Margarita Simonyan, pondered going to front, if he dies (youtu.be‚Ä¶). I’ve never heard Simonyan say anything that wasn’t calculated, so this line made me scratch my head a little. Simonyan is still all-in on the “special military operation,” of course, but it is strange to hear her death wish expressed this way.

Don’t her words come close to admitting what Putin’s soldiers need when headed to the front? I’m thinking of the Russian “meat assaults” and their use of soldiers to fire at their own, should they dare not advance or even retreat. Still, Simonyan’s words lean on such a common literary trope that they needn’t be seen as destabilizing. If there is one thing about Simonyan we can still be sure of, she is an expert information warrior.

Rule of Law

Apr 21, 2025

Dwight D. Eisenhower’s address from the White House on September 24, 1957, regarding his use of federal troops in Little Rock makes for interesting reading. Here’s a taste (www.eisenhowerlibrary.gov‚Ä¶):

The very basis of our individual rights and freedoms rests upon the certainty that the President and the Executive Branch of Government will support and insure the carrying out of the decisions of the Federal Courts, even, when necessary with all the means at the President’s command.

Unless the President did so, anarchy would result.

There would be no security for any except that which each one of us could provide for himself.

HT @HeidiLiFeldman@mastodon.social

Drone Warfare in Ukraine

Apr 19, 2025

In a 14-minute explainer, Anders Puck Nielsen discusses how “NATO has missed the drone revolution” youtu.be‚Ä¶. The R word is thrown around far too easily in military studies, just as it is in tech; however, Nielsen’s argument is no mere clich√©. Drones don’t just supplement other military hardware. In the large quantities in which they now appear, they change the very nature of battle. Wars of movement are once again giving way to wars of attrition, albeit in new ways.

See also the short piece by Valerii Zaluzhnyi that Nielsen talks about in his video: “How drones, data, and AI transformed our military‚Äîand why the US must follow suit,” defenseone.com‚Ä¶.

It seems western armies cannot afford any arrogance vis-√†-vis Ukraine. They need to learn from that country ºs armed forces, just as the latter will continue to benefit from our armaments.

White was a powerhouse of the genre in the 1930s, publishing more than 100 short stories and 17 novels, three of which were adapted into films, most notably Hitchcock’s “The Lady Vanishes” (1938).‚Ä¶

Harold and the Purple Crayon by Crockett Johnson (Harper & Brothers, 1950).

I introduced this book to my granddaughter yesterday (via video chat), and she adores it. Apparently it once made an impression on my son, too, because he said it had been his favorite. It's a simple story in which Harold takes a walk, creating the world as he goes with a big purple crayon.
